info.title: Installing the required PXE server components

abstract.para: This section explains how to install the necessary packages to support PXE booting in &productname; &productnumber;, including &grub;, DHCP, TFTP and/or HTTP components.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: To configure a PXE boot server on &productname; &productnumber;, you need to install several services and tools. Depending on your set-up, you may need the following:

listitem.para: The dnsmasq provides combination of a DNS server, a TFTP server and a DHCP server (DHCPv4 and DHCPv6) with limited IPv6 router advertisement (RA) support. It offers the following:
dnsmasq DHCP server: supports conditional delivery of DHCP options depending on request and client architecture for:
PXE boot requests using DHCPv4 and DHCPv6
HTTP boot requests using DHCPv4

note.title: Limitation of dnsmasq for HTTP boot over DHCPv6
note.para: Currently, dnsmasq does not support sending the required vendor-class DHCPv6 option.

listitem.para: dnsmasq TFTP server: supports delivery of bootloader files, kernel and initrd over TFTP while PXE boot.
dnsmasq DNS server: supports recursive resolution of the domain names and IP addresses for the client firmware and /etc/resolv.conf in the Installer/OS.
dnsmasq IPv6 RA: support to send IPv6 RA when PXE server is also acting as a router (configurability limited to "common RA pattern").
The kea &kea; is a DHCP server and a successor of the ISC DHCP server. It supports conditional delivery of DHCP options depending on request and client architecture for:
PXE boot requests using DHCPv4 and DHCPv6
HTTP boot requests using DHCPv4

note.title: Limitation of &kea; for HTTP Boot over DHCPv6
note.para: Currently, &kea; does not support sending the required vendor-class DHCPv6 option. For more information, see .

listitem.para: A TFTP server delivers the bootloader files, kernel and initrd over TFTP while PXE boot with kea is provided by the tftp package and not required for HTTP Boot. If you are using dnsmasq, you do not need the tftp package.
A web server such as the nginx package to serve installer images over HTTP.

note.title: Necessity for HTTP servers
note.para: HTTP and HTTPS servers such as nginx is effectively always needed; it's use case is not only restricted to HTTP Boot. In particular, you may need it in the following scenarios:

listitem.para: It is a basic requirement for HTTP Boot.
It is recommended for providing the squashfs.img. You can use root=live:tftp://.../squashfs.img in the boot command line.

It is also recommended for providing RPMs to &agama; in the inst.install_url=http://.../install/ boot command line parameter on a SLES-16.0-Full-*.inline.iso, along with installation profiles and other files for unattended installation.

The &grub; bootloader packages to provide network boot for supported architectures and methods. For example, the &x86-64; architecture provides two methods for network boot: BIOS and UEFI. Additionally, UEFI generally supports PXE (TFTP) and HTTP Boot. Other bootloaders such as pxelinux do not support UEFI and HTTP Boot.
Optionally, a router advertisement daemon for IPv6, such as the radvd package. It is required on &productnameshort; if it is also acting as router for an installer network to perform the following:
Configure routing on a network for PXE or HTTP Boot clients.
Enable DHCPv6 use on a network for PXE or HTTP Boot clients.

A system running &productname; &productnumber; with administrative privileges, registered to the SUSE Customer Center and configured with access to the appropriate online repositories using SUSEConnect.
Enabled SLE modules: Server Applications Module, Legacy Module and Basesystem Module.
Access to the SLE module repositories for network services and bootloaders.
A working internet connection to fetch packages.

section.title: Installing the packages
section.para: Use the following steps to install the core packages required for the PXE boot server.

procedure.title: Installing necessary packages for a PXE boot server

step.para: Install the &grub; boot loader and the nginx HTTP server as common requirements.
Run any one of the following command to install the essential packages for your approach:
kea for the DHCP server, tftp for the TFTP server
dnsmasq as the common provider for DHCP, DNS, and TFTP servers

note.title: Limitations of DHCP servers provided by &kea; and dnsmasq
note.para: HTTP boot over IPv6 is currently not supported by DHCP servers provided by the kea and dnsmasq packages. That is, it does not support to send a vendor-class option back to the HTTP client, as required by the UEFI specification.

step.para: Optionally, install additional architecture-specific &grub; targets if you plan to support other platforms.

note.title: How can the PXE server deliver &grub; packages to clients that are different from the server machine's architecture
note.para: The &grub; architecture specific noarch.rpm packages are included in the noarch subdirectory of the installation media/repository, regardless of the architecture of the machine on which the PXE server is set up. That is, you can install grub2-arm64-efi and grub2-powerpc-ieee1275 packages in a PXE server running on an &x86-64; machine, in order to support clients with an other architectures.

step.para: Optionally, you may install the shim package if you need UEFI Secure Boot for &x86-64; or &aarch64;, but do not want to use the files from the installation media ISO.
Optionally, install the router advertisement daemon radvd, if you want to use the PXE server as a router (not recommended for production networks).
Install the rsync utility to conveniently copy or sync the ISO and directory tree.
Ensure the services are installed but not yet started. Configuration will be covered in later sections.
